text: My budget summary; http://www.itv.com/news/2014-03-19/no-one-big-dramatic-shift-from-osbornes-budget/ …
author: tombradby

text: Interesting budget. Very political. Very targeted and directed; at business, at savers, at pensioners. No big crowd pleasing rabbit.
author: tombradby

text: Abolishes lowest rate for savers. Those saving 5k won't pay anything.
author: tombradby

text: These changes are pretty far-reaching and, let's remember, pensioners do vote...
author: tombradby

text: Multiple changes to people's pensions, basically giving them more flexibiity. 'No one will have to buy an annuity.'
author: tombradby

text: New pensioner bond launched, paying 2.8% for one year bond and 4% for a three year bond.
author: tombradby

text: Big changes to ISAs. Merges the cash and stock ISAs. Makes them more flexible and increases annual limit to 15k.
author: tombradby

text: Higher rate tax threshold rises for the first time this parliament. Not exactly what his backbenchers wanted, but a step on the way.
author: tombradby

text: He evidently relishes saying 'a penny off a pint for the second year running.'
author: tombradby

text: Alcohol prices rise with inflation, save for those on Scottish whisky (is there a referendum, by any chance?), cider and beer (which is cut)
author: tombradby

text: Bingo duty halved. We may laugh, but it is a section of the audience he badly needs to reach.
author: tombradby

text: Don't think environmental campaigners will be happy with some of these measures, but it is a very business focused budget so far.
author: tombradby

text: Let's see the detail, but these do sound like quite significant measures to cap energy bills for manufacturers.
author: tombradby

text: Vince Cable has been pushing for that very strongly.
author: tombradby

text: He doubles the investment allowance to 500k - and gets a huge cheer from the Tory benches.
author: tombradby

text: He announces the Alan Turing Institute, named after brilliant mathmetician who helped us win WW2, but was persecuted for his sexuality.
author: tombradby

text: For reference, we have just checked; last year's tax avoidance measures were predicted to save just under a billion a year.
author: tombradby

text: Not much of note so far.
author: tombradby

text: A grant to the Magna Carta Trust - and a dig against a man who betrays his brother and has to deal with unruly (union) barons; ie Ed M.
author: tombradby

text: It is astonishing how much money has been raised from this crack down in the last five years.
author: tombradby

text: More tax avoidance crack down, particularly on those who buy residential properties through companies.
author: tombradby

text: We've had all the lines already. We're all in this together. We have to fix the roof when the sun is shining. And so on...
author: tombradby

text: Not going to cut 0.7% contribution to overseas aid. That won't please the right wing press and backbenchers.
author: tombradby

text: Confirms it will be a neutral budget, ie; that it will give with one hand and take with the other (mainly through spending changes).
author: tombradby

text: A more resilient pound for a more resilient economy. Groans from the opposition. Terrible line.
author: tombradby

text: Moving to the new pound coin will take three years.
author: tombradby

text: Borrowing drops against last forecasts in the autumn statement; 108 billion this year (111 predicted). 95 next (against 96), then 75 (vs 79)
author: tombradby

text: Though, on the deficit, we should note this is a long way off from his original promise.
author: tombradby

text: There is no doubt these figures look very good for Osborne.
author: tombradby

text: 'We are growing faster than Germany, Japan and the USA.' One senses few things make him happier than being able to tell Ed Balls this.
author: tombradby

text: Growth figures haven't changed much from autumn statement and are down for some future years. In other words; growth is happening earlier.
author: tombradby

text: Last years's growth forecast for this year was 1.8, today it is 2.7.
author: tombradby

text: Interesting tone already. The Chancellor has evidently decided to wear a hair shirt. The economy is recovering, but there is no triumphalism
author: tombradby

text: Here we go, Mr Osborne on his feet for a Budget that could make or break his party's election prospects.
author: tombradby

text: Westminster awaits Mr Osborne's rabbit; http://www.itv.com/news/2014-03-19/today-well-see-how-smart-osborne-really-is/ …

text: Just spoken to Cameron in Bethlehem. He says he has no new information on the revelations about Rolls Royce and the Malaysia Air flight.
author: tombradby

text: Anyway, I felt the highlight was the Magnum Carta and the discussion of the ice cream wars of 1215.
author: tombradby

text: I think what Israeli MPs will take from this is; some stuff about how great peace would be, but he is basically behind us 100%
author: tombradby

text: I am not going to lecture you on how to run your peace process, but think of the possibilities that peace might bring, he adds.
author: tombradby

text: Cameron is being pretty trenchant here in his support for Israel.
author: tombradby

text: 'Delegitimising the State of Israel is wrong. It is abhorrent,' he says. 'And together we will defeat it.'
author: tombradby

text: 'With me, you have a PM whose belief in Israel is unbreakable,' Cameron says.
author: tombradby

text: Cameron finally gets to speak; If I was missing PMQs and looking for somewhere to spend a quiet Weds afternoon, clearly came to wrong place.
author: tombradby

text: More shouting. I wonder if David Cameron is ever going to get to speak?
author: tombradby

text: Netanyahu finishes! But now we have the leader of the opposition...
author: tombradby

text: Netanyahu can now barely get out a sentence without interruption. Someone needs to tell him less might be more...
author: tombradby

text: The refusal of the Palestinians to recognise the Jewish state is the root of the problem, not the settlement of it, Netanyahu says.
author: tombradby

text: There has been so much shouting, I have rather lost track of Netanyahu's speech, which perhaps was the intention.
author: tombradby

text: Left wing opposition MP who has taken exception to Netanyahu's history lesson is escorted out.
author: tombradby

text: This is the MP who was barracking Netanyahu http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Issawi_Frej …
author: tombradby

text: I think @JamieLinks that was about the height of it.
author: tombradby

text: Netanyahu's speech heavily interrupted by opposition members of the Knesset. Lots of shouting. This could go on a while...
author: tombradby

text: Thirteenth century politics, as sponsored by Walls Ice Cream, perhaps.
author: tombradby

text: Netanyahu talks about history of political thought in the UK. His translator refers to the Magnum Carta. Interesting.
author: tombradby

text: Israeli PM Netanyahu gets shouted at as he takes to the stage to welcome Cameron.
author: tombradby

text: Well, you know, politicians are politicians the world over.
author: tombradby

text: So, am sitting at the Knesset in Jerusalem, waiting for Cameron to give his address. Introductory speeches supposed to be brief, but...

text: Cameron says on plane travel ban could extend to Russian MPs, which should sort it...

text: Verdict; she doesn't rub Dave's nose in it, but she doesn't offer an awful lot of help and support either.

text: Back to English at the end...
author: tombradby

text: Tax payers should never again have to foot the bill for banks making mistakes, she says. Popular, for sure, but easier said than done.

text: Cutting red tape the second carrot.

text: Hint of reform on freedom of movement the only carrot I can see for Cameron so far.
author: tombradby

text: Talking about freedom of movement, she says 'we need to acknowledge mistakes and tackle them'. But no indication as to what that means.
author: tombradby

text: We need to reform the political shape of Europe in keeping with the times, she says.
author: tombradby

text: A lady just fainted at the back of the crowd watching Merkel.
author: tombradby

text: And she notably seems to blame the Germans for the First World War, as well as the second.
author: tombradby

text: Very generous speech from Merkel. What would have happened to Europe if the UK had not stood up for freedom, sometimes alone, she says.
author: tombradby

text: Now she switches to German...
author: tombradby

text: She is addressing expectations. I am caught between the devil and the deep blue sea, she says.
author: tombradby

text: She is speaking in English. Of course, I am sure Dave could comfortably address the Reichstag in German...
author: tombradby

text: A well-judged speech from Bercow introducing Merkel.
author: tombradby

text: The Royal Gallery is as packed as the tube in rush hour to hear Merkel. Anyone would think she was quite powerful...
author: tombradby

text: Man made climate change is one of the most serious threats to this country, says the PM at PMQs. His backbenchers will love that.

text: Boundless optimism in my local town...

text: The Autumn Statement; snap verdict http://www.itv.com/news/2013-12-05/osbornes-message-is-growth-is-up-up-up/ …
author: tombradby

text: I don't think this is a day Ed B is going to look back on with affection.
author: tombradby

text: This heckling is pretty sustained.
author: tombradby

text: All the polls show that is their best line of attack and the one that has traction with voters.
author: tombradby

text: Ed Balls surely needs to claim there is economic recovery, but it is only going to work for the rich...
author: tombradby

text: This is an important moment for Ed Balls. A very tricky day, but he needs to land a few punches.
author: tombradby

text: Ed Balls gets VERY loudly barracked.
author: tombradby

text: This isn't the budget! @faisalislam
author: tombradby

text: And he's down again. So really no surprises at all.
author: tombradby

text: So far, virtually everything in this budget was leaked.
author: tombradby

text: National Insurance axed for the Under 21s (for employers).
author: tombradby

text: Cancelling these rises over the past few years has cost £22 billion, he says.
author: tombradby

text: Next year's fuel duty rise cancelled. Loud cheers from the coalition benches.
author: tombradby

text: Second interruption (because of the noise).
author: tombradby

text: Marriage tax allowance is in.
author: tombradby

text: ie; aimed at smaller shops.
author: tombradby

text: And another; retail outlets with a value of less than 50k get a rates discount worth 1k.
author: tombradby

text: Here is the business headline; rate rise capped at 2% (he claims they were expecting 3.2%).
author: tombradby

text: Tax relief to be extended to regional theatres. Interesting? Not sure what impact it will have.
author: tombradby

text: This is quite important; Osborne claiming that business tax cuts lead directly to higher growth.
author: tombradby

text: Osborne abolishes cap on student places. Interesting -- but a lot of Tories say there are already too many students.
author: tombradby

text: Not many new headlines so far, save for the growth figures. I am guessing he must have a flourish at the end.
author: tombradby

text: Effusive support of M Gove. Thumbing his nose at Mr Clegg, perhaps (re yesterday's row).
author: tombradby

text: It makes you realise just how much of it there was going on in the boom.
author: tombradby

text: One of the extraordinary things is just how much money has been made in successive budgets by cutting down on tax evasion.
author: tombradby

text: Rather overdue as a measure, one might think.
author: tombradby

text: Or to put it another way; Russian or Chinese billionaires buying up property in London will have to pay capital gains tax when they sell.
author: tombradby

text: More stuff on tax evasion that seems somewhat opaque (will work out when I have a minute) but headline is foreign investors will pay CGT.
author: tombradby

text: And, obviously, we all want to work until we are 100 don't we!
author: tombradby

text: Increasing the pension age really does save them a very large amount of money.
author: tombradby

text: Sounds like Overseas Development has just had its ring fence removed?
author: tombradby

text: Whitehall depts going to underspend by £7 billion this year - an example of good financial management, he says.
author: tombradby

text: I don't think there is much doubt the overall message is going to be; austerity goes on and on and on...
author: tombradby

text: And now that is a point Osborne is making. Growth alone does not get us out of the hole, he says.
author: tombradby

text: It says something about the state we're in that this genuinely good news does so little to change the overall picture.
author: tombradby

text: Borrowing drops a lot. 111 this year (prediction 120), 96 next (108), 79 in 15/16 (96).
author: tombradby

text: We're still not out of deficit territory until 2018/19 -- much later than he originally promised.
author: tombradby

text: Unemployment predicted to be down to 7%in 2015 against a budget prediction of 7.9%.
author: tombradby

text: And the predictions today are that it will level off after next year.
author: tombradby

text: Though one might say that is because we are playing catch-up.
author: tombradby

text: He says our economy is now growing faster than that of any other advanced economy, including Germany in the USA.
author: tombradby

text: And 2.4 next year as against prediction of 1.8 -- though the predictions in the year after that are lower than in the budget.
author: tombradby

text: Growth dramatically up this year, he says. 1.4 compared to budget prediction of 0.6.
author: tombradby

text: And there was no double dip, he says.
author: tombradby

text: Now he is really sticking it to Labour by saying that the fall in the size of the economy was bigger in the crash than thought.
author: tombradby

text: Blimey -- can't remember a budget or mini-budget ever being interrupted by the Speaker before.
author: tombradby

text: Just what we wanted to hear...
author: tombradby

text: More difficult decisions, he says. Oh, good.
author: tombradby

text: Osborne getting quite political already. I suppose that is no surprise.
author: tombradby

text: One of the all time low points in eight and a half years as Political Editor here.
author: tombradby

text: I have been reflecting on the way MPs questioned Mr Rusbridger's patriotism yesterday and I must say it really gives me the creeps.
author: tombradby

text: I'd say DC thinks it's the '92 election (vote Labour and the lights go out) and EM that its '45 (time for change now the war is over).

text: David Cameron seemed quite fired up today, but I am not sure he has yet nailed the public mood http://www.itv.com/news/2013-10-02/cameron-appears-fired-up-and-hungry-to-win-next-election/ …

text: @agendaitv yes, the gratuitous attack on Blue Peter has not excited as much comment as it perhaps should have.

text: And, whilst I think DC is winning the economic argument with the public, I think EM is riding the general mood better.
author: tombradby

text: I think he will need to find more memorable and meaningful things to say about the future to win.
author: tombradby

text: Conclusion; more fired up than expected, reasonably authoritative, better than last 2 years, but mostly about what he is already doing.

text: Social work is 'vital and noble' (calls for a round of applause). Not what you normally hear from a Tory leader.

text: The Land of Opportunity. Repeat ad nauseam. Why do all speeches need a catchphrase these days?

text: You'd have to give him this; he seems quite fired up.

text: He is intending to fight the next election squarely on the public finances.

text: In the 25 years of covering politics, i have never heard a senior politician make an out and out commitment to running budget surpluses.

text: Wow, this is revolutionary; a surplus in good times as an insurance against bad times.

text: There is a pretty clear argument in this speech, whatever you think of George Osborne.

text: This rather reminds me of a Billy Graham meeting. And I generally mean that as a compliment.

text: He says he will reverse planned corporation tax cut and planned business rate rise. Got it?

text: They love this and that's no surprise; it's good.

text: Not sure about his economic argument. It's as if the euro crisis never happened.

text: This is interesting. He is completely fluent and relaxed, but many of the best lines are clearly pre-scripted. Tricky to pull off.

text: This style of speaking really suits him. It's authentic.

text: That suggests to me a lot of votes are in play for them come election day.

text: Our headline, I think; we are no one's little brother.

text: Labour would wreck the recovery, he says. The Tories would give us the wrong kind of recovery. Interesting line.

text: Pensions not included in welfare cap, immigrants must speak English before claiming benefits...a lot of politics in this today.

text: So Pickles and Grayling have taken a big hit, but May, Hammond, Cable and even Maria Miller seem to have got off (relatively) lightly.

text: Here is how it looks; Home Office 6%. Transport 9%. Justice 10%. FCO 8%. Treasury 10%. Cabinet Office 10%. DCMS 7%. Business 6%.

author: tombradby

text: Interesting politics; MOD and Home Office do relatively well, Local Govt and Justice take a bigger hit.

text: Putting out the facts would have taken about a minute. The rest of this (long) speech is all politics.

text: And to May, though perhaps with less feeling. She is a leadership candidate, Hague isn't.

author: tombradby

text: The big losers so far; civil servants (pay) and local councils.

text: This is the announcement from yesterday; some of the current under-spend will be switched to capital expenditure.

text: The 1% cap on public sector pay rises is extended another year. Ouch.
author: tombradby

text: So there will be another 1.5 billion pounds of spending cuts next year, but hard to know the impact when there is such a big under-spend.
author: tombradby

text: He achieved the under-spend by noticing that govt departments mostly go on spending splurges at the end of the year and stopping them.
author: tombradby

text: That gives him some cash to play with.
author: tombradby

text: This is also interesting and important; government departments have come in with huge under-spends this year (11 billion).
author: tombradby

text: This may actually be the most important announcement today.
author: tombradby

text: So, for example, the new Governor could announce that he was keeping interest rates at current levels for 2, 3 or 4 years.
author: tombradby

text: This is important; to cut a long story short, he is keeping the 2% inflation target, but giving the Bank of England more leeway.
author: tombradby

text: He announced in the Autumn Statement that he was going to miss his debt target. He has just said it will be pushed back another year.
author: tombradby

text: The figures (from 2011/12) read 121/120.9/119.8/108.4. So he only just manages to get borrowing down.
author: tombradby

text: These borrowing figures include the proceeds of selling QE coupons. Strip them out and borrowing only just falls.
author: tombradby

text: Unemployment will peak at 8%, which is lower than the 8.2% predicted.
author: tombradby

text: Growth predicted to be 0.6 vs the 1.2 predicted in the Autumn Statement.
author: tombradby

text: Growth heavily downgraded even from Autumn Statement. In fact, halved this year.
author: tombradby

text: In other words, poor growth is, he argues, due to lower exports.
author: tombradby

text: He is drawing our attention to the poor economic conditions overseas to explain why our exports are weak.

author: tombradby

text: Re Mad Men...things may have been improved, but does 4 women chief execs in the FTSE100 suggest we have further to go?
author: tombradby

text: Given that there are only four female chief execs in the FSTE 100, we'll also be discussing whether there is some way still to go...
author: tombradby

text: Because that worked really well for the government. #itvagenda
author: tombradby

text: It is the official 'Don't Panic' edition. #itvagenda
author: tombradby

text: I'll be joined by a fantastic and eclectic panel; Ross Kemp, Martin Sorrell, Margot James and Joan Bakewell. #itvagenda
author: tombradby

text: Plus the world of Mad Men is back on our screens. Have things really got better for women in the workplace?
author: tombradby

text: We'll discuss whether there is real damage to Brand Cameron. Is it mid-term froth, or something bigger?
author: tombradby

text: We are going to discuss a potential fuel strike on tonight's #itvagenda. If we behaved like that last week, what happens if it is for real?
author: tombradby

text: @victoriaarbiter Ah, Vanilla Sky...Nope. Sorry. Can't explain that one either.
author: tombradby

text: We were doing quite well with thrillers up until Green Zone bombed. Then Hollywood gave up trying to do anything that added up.
author: tombradby

text: But looking at what is generally on; maybe making no sense is the key to box office gold?
author: tombradby

text: @allanholloway I'm hoping you will find Shadow Dancer makes sense. I tried hard enough to make sure it did...
author: tombradby

text: Also saw Colombiana, which was a bit better. It didn't really add up either, but we'll gloss over that.
author: tombradby

text: But then...does change reality. So it makes no sense even on the basis of its own premise.
author: tombradby

text: So he finds the bomber (rather quickly, on the third attempt).
author: tombradby

text: I mean, the idea is that you can't change reality, right? You can only relive the last eight minutes so that you can find the bomber.
author: tombradby

text: And then Source Code, where they didn't even bother to try and make everything add up.
author: tombradby

text: But because Inception made a lot of money, we got The Adjustment Bureau, which was entertaining enough, but didn't make much sense to me.
author: tombradby

text: To those who have asked; I haven't seen Inception yet, though mean to soon.
author: tombradby

text: Just watched the film 'Source Code,' which made absolutely no sense at all.
author: tombradby

text: The government has been utterly inept, it's true, but I am not sure they can be held entirely responsible for this complete insanity.
author: tombradby

text: It is hard to believe this is the same country that survived the Blitz.
author: tombradby

text: Perhaps we should start exporting national hysteria, because we are damned good at it.
author: tombradby

text: The fuel pump scenes on the news appear to be happening in a parallel universe. Bonkers.
author: tombradby

text:
What do you mean there might not be a strike?
#haveiwokenuponmars?
author: tombradby

text: Have filled the car with petrol, but can't go anywhere now just in case I use it all before the strike starts.

text: BTW, I really don't understand this chaos at the pumps. They haven't even called a strike yet. What's wrong with us?

text: @DPMcBride I wonder if it will embolden the Blairites, who have, by and large, kept their counsel so far.

text: The tectonic plates may be shifting at Westminster, but slower than the polls suggest; http://www.itv.com/news/2012-03-27/power-balance-are-the-tories-in-real-trouble-after-a-bad-week-at-westminster/ …
author: tombradby

text: Great ratings again this week; 1.1 million #itvagenda
author: tombradby

text: We discuss a report on the riots last August (was advertising to blame?), the Tory donor scandal and the great talent show face-off.
author: tombradby

text: Great guests this week; William Hague, Anthony Horowitz, Paralymic athlete Tanni Grey-Thompson and Jane Moore from The Sun. #itvagenda
author: tombradby

text: Welcome to Twitter @louisefennell, my cousin and author of 'Dead Rich.' Better late than never!!
author: tombradby

text: @SirSocks Except the bad news. Not brilliant news management...
author: tombradby

text: @SirSocks No
author: tombradby

text: My v v brief guide to the budget; http://www.itv.com/news/2012-03-21/budget-2012-the-key-announcements-and-what-they-mean/ …
author: tombradby

text: Am very surprised Ed M went on cut in 50p rate (which even the OBR says is not raising money) and not the massive hit on pensioners.
author: tombradby

text: So there you have it. Basically, corporation tax down and personal allowance up, paid for by pensioners and pulling out of Afghanistan.
author: tombradby

text: Onto the finale; raising the personal allowance (ie; the amount at which you start to pay tax). But only just over £3 a week in real terms.
author: tombradby

text: So, you will only lose it completely if you are paid more than 60k.
author: tombradby

text: Only those people earning more than 50k will lose child benefit. It will then be tapered up to 60k.
author: tombradby

text: But not until next year and small print shows treasury expect to lose £2.4 billion this year as people delay payments.
author: tombradby

text: He has obviously got the independent OBR (auditor) to back him on this. Says his new wealth taxes will raise five times as much.
author: tombradby

text: But this is analysis by the same treasury officials who, er, said the 50p rate would raise £2.7 billion.
author: tombradby

text: The 'book cost' of cutting the tax is 100 million, but he says there are other distortions (like less VAT from less spending).
author: tombradby

text: He cuts the 50p rate to 45p. Treasury officials have apparently concluded it raises no money. He suggests Labour fiddled the analysis.
author: tombradby

text: He is capping complicated tax reliefs used by the wealthy. The general anti-avoidance rule could also be interesting...
author: tombradby

text: Plus a new rate of stamp duty of 7% on homes more than £2 million.
author: tombradby

text: Ah, those wealthy folk who have bought properties through offshore companies are getting hit; an annual charge. £15k on a £3 million house.
author: tombradby

text: He is not cutting fuel duty. I suspect that will annoy a lot of people.
author: tombradby

text: Corporation tax cut by another 1p, but it's expensive. It costs 920 million by the end of the forecast period.
author: tombradby

text: He gets £1.5 billion from getting out of Afghanistan and £1 billion from pensioners.
author: tombradby

text: So that (more or less) pays for the other half of the cost of raising the allowance for the rest of us...
author: tombradby

text: If you take into account inflation, it is a tax rise for pensioners. V unpopular, I would have thought. But raises him £1billion.
author: tombradby

text: Pensioners currently have a personal allowance of more than 10k. That will be frozen until the general personal allowance catches up.
author: tombradby

text: If you are over 65, you have a higher personal allowance (so pay less tax). This will now be frozen. It is a tax rise on pensioners.
author: tombradby

text: Okay, this is a big deal. Doesn't sound like much, but pensioners are getting their personal allowances frozen.
author: tombradby

text: He irons out VAT 'anomalies' on items like sports drinks and hot takeaway food.
author: tombradby

text: A lot of small measures; a reflection, I think, of the fact he has little money to spend.
author: tombradby

text: So it is the Wallace and Gromit budget. Perhaps not a good headline...
author: tombradby

text: Video games and TV shows get the same tax credits as films.
author: tombradby

text: Praise for Boris (his presumed future rival for the Tory leadership). Bet that was through gritted teeth!
author: tombradby

text: Talking about transport infrastructure in the north of England. Interesting political bid for lost northern voters.
author: tombradby

text: The theory is that if you don't have thousands of troops overseas, you don't need an emergency reserve...
author: tombradby

text: To recap so far; getting out of Afghanistan will save us £1.5 billion, which will be used to fund a tax cut for the lowest paid.
author: tombradby

text: Has a dig at Gordon for selling some of our gold reserves...
author: tombradby

text: In other words; no war, no reserve needed. This will pay for about half of the cost of raising the personal allowance.
author: tombradby

text: This is critical. Now we are coming out of Afghanistan, he is putting the contingency reserve back into the pot. Will save £1.5 billion
author: tombradby

text: ...in the welfare budget IF it is to keep spending on other departments at the current level.
author: tombradby

text: Okay, welfare spending; this is complicated but new assumptions by the OBR says that govt will need to find 10 billion more of savings...
author: tombradby

text: Borrowing down a billion a year or so for the next few years. Neither here nor there, one might say, given the scale of our deficit.
author: tombradby

text: Confirms this is a fiscally neutral budget; ie tax cuts will be paid for by other tax rises or spending cuts.
author: tombradby

text: Growth up 0.1 percent this year and down 0.1 percent next year on previous forecast.
author: tombradby

text: Economy doing better, he says, but only tiniest alteration in growth forecasts.
author: tombradby

text: Unashamedly pro business rhetoric so far...
author: tombradby

text: All parties do it. But if the polling data tells them that is what we think, why do they need to keep telling us what we think?
author: tombradby

text: The way modern political strategy works is that you look at the polling data and repeat the best finding over and over and over again.
author: tombradby

text: What do you think the chances of are of Labour concluding the coalition is 'out of touch' today?
author: tombradby

text: So President Obama joked about 'tucking Dave up in bed' on Air Force One. Oh dear oh dear oh dear... #thegrimbromance
author: tombradby

text: Will cost Treasury £5.1 billion, to be paid for by two big new spending cuts and other tax rises (eg tycoon tax).
author: tombradby

text: About to break on News at Ten; personal allowance to rise to £9,205. An extra £346 a year in the pockets of basic rate tax payers.
author: tombradby

text: And I feel the sceptics will be happy with the shirt/tie combo...
author: tombradby

text: Def worth a watch, I'd say.
author: tombradby

text: I guess I would say this, but fantastic edition of itvagenda# tonight. Great guests, nice chemistry, thoughtful chat and some laughs.
author: tombradby

text: On tonight's itvagenda; http://www.itv.com/news/update/2012-03-19/tonights-topics-on-the-agenda-with-tom-bradby/ … via @itvnews
author: tombradby

text: Nothing like having the man who just vacated the hot seat...
author: tombradby

text: Plus give us some info on what schemes treasury officials like to dust off when the Chancellor wants more cash...
author: tombradby

text: The Chancellor apparently plans a giveaway budget without having anything to giveway. Alastair Darling may be able to help do the maths.
author: tombradby

text: We'll be discussing the govt's new plan on a minimum price for booze, budget priorities and the coverage of SamCam's trip to the USA.
author: tombradby

text: Great guests on The Agenda tonight; Alastair Darling, Amanda Platell of the Mail, Andy Street of John Lewis and the actress Fiona Shaw.
author: tombradby

text: Cameron's closest aide Steve Hilton on the bus with us this morning and somewhat frustrated by the hanging around. Welcome to our world!
author: tombradby

text: Massive congrats to my friend @markpougatch for winning Sports Broadcaster of the Year award. Richly deserved.
author: tombradby

text: A Revolution in Washington; http://blog.itv.com/news/tombradby/2012/03/a-revolution-in-washington/ …
author: tombradby

text: The White House is the only place I have seen David Cameron look a little overawed.
author: tombradby

text: I guess it must just be a recognition that many of our soldiers die alongside their own.
author: tombradby

text: Obama has really laid on the love here in Washington. It is quite hard to see why. Their personal chemistry seems good but not amazing...
author: tombradby

text: Fantastic viewing figures for last night's Agenda (1.1 million average, peaking at 1.7). 400,00 up on last week and almost double Newsnight.
author: tombradby

text: Am now at Heathrow, waiting to board Cameron Force One. I don't think we'll be getting some Prime Ministerial M and Ms...
author: tombradby

text: Think the show is hitting its stride and have had some very nice comments. Will retweet a few...
author: tombradby

text: Feel relieved my shirt/tie combo passed the style test last night, esp with the all important @tnewtondunn, @jameschappers and @chrisship.
author: tombradby

text: Am going to be very upset if I get grief tonight.
author: tombradby

text: By the way, I feel I am going to get a lot more plaudits for my shirt/tie combination this week. Uh-huh. You just wait...
author: tombradby

text: And finally is there something about Harry? Is he playing a blinder or are we just going soft on the royals?
author: tombradby

text: Talking about the Special Relationship (and whether we'd fight a few less foreign wars without it), whether we should tax wages not wealth..
author: tombradby

text: Great guests and subjects on The Agenda tonight; Yvette Cooper, Fraser Nelson of the Spectator, James Caan and Rachel Johnson...
author: tombradby

text: @doreenwilks think this one may run for a while...
author: tombradby

text: @markaustinitv that's me in the poor house, then...
author: tombradby

text: Well, I'm sure George will give me the credit if that is his answer!
author: tombradby

text: The reason I picked 15 years ago is that it takes us back to roughly the start of the boom...
author: tombradby

text: @billythebrit From memory, Notting Hill was pretty expensive even 14 years ago.
author: tombradby

text: At any rate, it would settle that particular argument though not necessarily broader ones about the rights and wrongs of taxing wealth.
author: tombradby

text: I would have thought anyone who has bought a house worth more than 2 million in the last 15 yrs probably counts as wealthy.
author: tombradby

text: In that case, you pay nothing. When the house is sold, the next owner starts paying.
author: tombradby

text: I don't agree my plan is complicated. If your house falls into the band, you have the option to show you have owned it more than 15 yrs.
author: tombradby

text: That way you get rid of the 'income poor widower' argument and wallop lots of Russians. Simple.
author: tombradby

text: And maybe I am stupid, but surely the answer to the mansion tax arguments is to exempt anyone who has owned their house more than 15 yrs?
author: tombradby

text: @allegrastratton has settled in rather well at Newsnight. She looks very comfortable.
author: tombradby

text: Although, actually, I quite like vanilla.
author: tombradby

text: Still, at least it wasn't 'vanilla'.
author: tombradby

text: I see my shirt/tie combo last night was a somewhat divisive issue. Maybe I need to up the lighting in the dressing room...
author: tombradby

text: We'll be discussing gay marriage, how the coalition is working and why - from Downton to Call the Midwife to Titanic - we love nostalgia TV.
author: tombradby

text: Looking forward to this week's edition of The Agenda. Joining me are Nick Clegg, Mariella Frostrup, Rachel Sylvester and Digby Jones.
author: tombradby

text: And finally we'll talk about the Oscars and the state of British film. Was Cameron smart or stupid to say we would make 'commercial' films?
author: tombradby

text: We'll debate Leveson today and the fact that The Sun's readers don't seem to be recoiling from these revelations...
author: tombradby

text: Now we know the top 1% of earners pay 30% of all income tax, we'll ask if it is time stop bashing them - or should they pay more?
author: tombradby

text: Okay, just getting ready for the first edition of The Agenda. We'll have Boris Johnson, Allison Pearson, Jenny Agutter and Brendan Barber.
author: tombradby

text: That is terrible, terrible news about Marie Colvin. She was a legendary figure and rightly so.
author: tombradby

text:
@MrHarryCole 
Well, I'm hoping you'll like it...
It's a bit different, anyway.
And very nice that ITV is doing it.
author: tombradby

text: @MrHarryCole New current affairs discussion show runs for eight weeks, starting after next week's News at Ten...
author: tombradby

text: But next week is a different story...
author: tombradby

text: Pilot of The Agenda tonight. Looks like we'll be discussing Greece, the Lansley heckle and the Sun on Sunday. Sadly, you won't see it...
author: tombradby

text: Worth listening to if you thought you knew the man.
author: tombradby

text: It has taken me a while to catch up with the fascinating Desert Island Discs edition with @johnprescott. Great intvw; interesting and human.
author: tombradby

text: @Gabethevegan I think I was defending a free press as the bulwark of democracy.
author: tombradby

text: I guess this week we'd discuss hacking, maybe whether Cameron should ditch the NHS reforms, maybe the BAFTAs. Any other bright ideas?
author: tombradby

text: Now back and working on my new show 'The Agenda' which is due to start airing after News at Ten on Mon night a fortnight from today.
author: tombradby

text: Had a great 24 hours in Berlin. Premiere went really well, press screenings apparently likewise. Clive and Andrea were good fun.
author: tombradby

text: Just done the red carpet with Clive Owen and Andrea R in Berlin for European premiere of Shadow Dancer. Slightly surreal!
author: tombradby

text: It will be interesting to see what happens...
author: tombradby

text: I don't know what will come out of Leveson, but I do know this; very few cabinet ministers are in favour of statutory regulation.
author: tombradby

text: It was only half a joke, because Blair was all powerful, the Tories were weak and it did feel at times like the Mail was the opposition.
author: tombradby

text: And a strong, vibrant press is a good counter-weight. You may recall the time when P Dacre was called the 'Leader of the Opposition'.
author: tombradby

text: We can all agree that the tabloid press got out of control. But my point is that we sometimes have very powerful govts (Thatcher, Blair).
author: tombradby

text: @ZacGoldsmith @tom_watson You have to have the wisdom of Solomon to know what the answer is and I think we can all agree I don't have that.
author: tombradby

text: Because I think a powerful, aggressive press is a significant factor in helping to keep them honest.
author: tombradby

text: I am not sure any of us should want to live in a world where the power balance tips back towards politicians.
author: tombradby

text: I don't think anyone thinks that any tabloid has a perfect record on intrusion. But govts are usually scared of the Mail and that has value.
author: tombradby

text: And to force big institutions to change course or take action (eg the Stephen Lawrence case).
author: tombradby

text: The best defence of the Mail is surely that it is one of the few organisations with the strength to stand up to govts (eg the Blair era).
author: tombradby

text: Strange interview with H Grant by Evan on Today. Grant is an intelligent and powerful advocate of his cause and rather got the better of it.
author: tombradby

text: Slaughter at PMQs. Time to give Mr Lansley the bullet? http://blog.itv.com/news/tombradby/2012/02/slaughter-at-pmqs/ …
author: tombradby

text: There's no doubt about this; Ed M was outstanding and Dave C was slaughtered. Lansley is killing the Tories re-election chances.
author: tombradby

text: DC tries the happy families gag again, but this time it doesn't work.
author: tombradby

text: To no one's surprise, Ed M goes on the NHS. Doing well so far. DC playing on impossible wicket.
author: tombradby

text: Not quite sure why you have to be stripped of all electronics, swipe cards and just about everything else before going in.
author: tombradby

text: Just had my journalist visa renewed at the US Embassy. One of life's singularly joyless experiences.
author: tombradby

text: We don't talk much about the threat an undemocratic China constitutes, but maybe we should; http://blog.itv.com/news/tombradby/2012/02/the-new-world-order/ …
author: tombradby

text: And even more helpfully, here is a link to Tom's book. http://tinyurl.com/7xbzrol
author: tombradby

text: It also has the best title ever for a political book; 'Why I am right and everyone else is wrong.'
author: tombradby

text: If you are interested in politics, might be worth buying the new book by @TomHarrisMP It's funny and interesting.
author: tombradby

text: @robertmooreitv good point; an example of how different the US and the UK currently feel...
author: tombradby

text: @paulweatherly Actually, I thought he was slighly misquoted on that. But the 14% tax rate is a fact it is hard to get past.
author: tombradby

text: Just seen an ad from Lambeth council. 'Central govt cut our income by a third, so we have to cut services.' And pay to advertise that fact?
author: tombradby

text: I have only been following the US race at a distance, but I don't see how a millionaire who pays income tax at 14% can possibly win.
author: tombradby

text: @adamboultonSKY er....yes, good point.
author: tombradby

text: Man and wife charged. End of.
author: tombradby

text: BTW; why did Keir Starmer have to announce this in such a dramatic fashion? Wouldn't putting out a simple statement have sufficed?
author: tombradby

text: @Sknowles3 I thought it was rather pertinent, actually. If you treat your wife of many years that badly, it can end like this...
author: tombradby

text: What a mess.
author: tombradby

text: Political moral of the day; it's not a very good idea to run off with your adviser...
author: tombradby

text: Politics these days is a tale of two conflicts; http://itv.co/y6rHBg
author: tombradby

text: An informative blog from the excellent @ITVRichard http://itv.co/yfIGiy
author: tombradby

text: @charliebstill No, we don't.
author: tombradby

text: Cameron banging on and on about Labour's opposition to welfare reform. Vaguely effective, I suppose. But he doesn't sound good on the NHS.
author: tombradby

text: Ed M is turning into quite an effective tribune of the people, but it can be a double-edged sword as Neil Kinnock found.
author: tombradby

text: But Labour's approach on the City is starting to look a tad opportunistic and Cameron ended well.
author: tombradby

text: Interesting PMQs. Ed's tone is def getting better. Calmer. Cameron's lines are sounding a bit tired.
author: tombradby

text: I bet Fred the Shred still doesn't have to wait for a replacement bus service at 11.30 at night...
author: tombradby

text: @bennyghana No
author: tombradby

text: God, how I hate South West Trains. Engineering works, overcrowded carriages and not enough buses. Useless. Sundance seems a long way away...
author: tombradby

text: No one is going to mourn the fact that Sir Fred is now plain Fred. But it reminds me just how many politicians used to worship at his feet.
author: tombradby

text: @jameschappers 7 so far!
author: tombradby

text: And in the other news....Sarko has a pop at the UK on our lack of industrial policy. Again.
author: tombradby

text: Finally (because I am boring even myself); would it be better to simply nationalise RBS even if it meant writing off much of the £45bn?
author: tombradby

text: @steverichards14 Just to be clear, you are saying that politicians should decide pay and bonus structure of RBS execs?
author: tombradby

text: Interesting piece by @jeremywarnerUK which chews over some interesting arguments for nationalising RBS http://tgr.ph/wpu9PE
author: tombradby

text: PS. We invested £45 billion in RBS. If we sold our stake today, we'd get £25 billion back.
author: tombradby

text: Nor do I understand that of any of the political parties. Somebody has to decide. Today, right now. So, who? And what level is ok?
author: tombradby

text: @steverichards14 Steve, I'm not agreeing with you or disagreeing with you. I'm just saying I don't understand your position.
author: tombradby

text: Surely there is an argument for saying he should not be paid a penny more than the PM? Would that be your position?
author: tombradby

text: @steverichards14 But that's still not an answer, Steve. Who should set it now? And what figure (roughly/exactly) do you think would be ok?
author: tombradby

text: Politicians cannot say they want an independent, fully commercial bank - and then say they want to control its pay policy.
author: tombradby

text: We can all debate whether he deserves his bonus. My point is simple; who should decide? The board? Or Number Ten?
author: tombradby

text: @steverichards14 But that's general, I'm talking specifics. Who should set Hester's pay and bonus level today and what would be acceptable?
author: tombradby

text: Fair point @archiebunkerUK, but we are talking in the specific, not the general. The question is who should set the pay of RBS execs.
author: tombradby

text: @steverichards14 okay, steve, what's your answer then? What should Hester earn? And who should decide?
author: tombradby

text: If the board sets the pay of leading execs, it's a bank. If politicians do, it's a government department.
author: tombradby

text: @tim_brannigan True, Tim, but what is the answer? My point is that you either run it as a commercial bank or a govt dept. You can't do both.
author: tombradby

text: The Complicated Case of Mr Hester's bonus; http://blog.itv.com/news/tombradby/2012/01/the-complicated-case-of-mr-hesters-bonus/ …
author: tombradby

text: Hmmm. A lot of responses...I suspect this is one we will pick up again in the morning.
author: tombradby

text: It seems to me the political question for the week is this; is it time for the politicians to stop pretending they can RBS at arm's length?
author: tombradby

text: Discuss. Ad nauseam. For the rest of this week.
author: tombradby

text: Or was it foolish of the political class to pretend this was really anything other than a nationalised bank?
author: tombradby

text: Or is it just media hype (for once, this seems unlikely given the level of public outrage)?
